claim: Children born in 2010 are teenagers in 2025

supporting.text: Children born in 2010 will be 15 years old in 2025, which falls within the age range of 13-19 commonly defined as teenage years.

attacks.text: Children born in 2010 will be 15 years old in 2025, which falls within the age range of 13-19 commonly defined as teenage years.
Some cultures define teenage years differently, such as starting at 12 or ending at 18, which could exclude 15-year-olds from being considered teenagers in certain contexts.
The internationally accepted definition of teenage years is 13-19, as recognized by most demographic and psychological studies, making cultural variations statistically insignificant.
A child born on December 31, 2010, would still be 14 years old on January 1, 2025, and thus not yet a teenager by the 13-19 definition.
The vast majority of children born in 2010 would have turned 15 by the end of 2025, making the edge case of December 31 births negligible for the general claim.

supporting.text: The term 'teenager' refers to individuals whose age ends with 'teen' (13 to 19), and 15 is explicitly included in this range.

attacks.text: The term 'teenager' refers to individuals whose age ends with 'teen' (13 to 19), and 15 is explicitly included in this range.
The claim is about children born in 2010 being teenagers in 2025, but A2 does not directly address the age calculation for those born in 2010.
In 2025, children born in 2010 will be 15 years old, which falls within the 13-19 range mentioned in A2, thus supporting the claim.
Some cultures or contexts may define 'teenager' differently, not strictly based on the 'teen' suffix in age numbers.
The English language universally defines 'teenager' as ages 13-19, making cultural variations irrelevant to the claim's validity in standard usage.

supporting.text: By 2025, individuals born in 2010 will have entered adolescence, a developmental stage associated with teenage years.

attacks.text: By 2025, individuals born in 2010 will have entered adolescence, a developmental stage associated with teenage years.
Adolescence is not strictly defined by age and may vary culturally or individually, so not all individuals born in 2010 will necessarily be teenagers in 2025.
While adolescence can vary, the widely accepted definition of a teenager is someone aged 13–19, which applies to those born in 2010 by 2025.
Some individuals born in 2010 may have developmental delays or conditions that prevent them from being classified as teenagers in 2025.
Such cases are exceptions and do not negate the general applicability of the claim to the majority of individuals born in 2010.

supporting.text: Educational systems globally classify students aged 13-19 as teenagers, and 15-year-olds are part of this group.

attacks.text: Educational systems globally classify students aged 13-19 as teenagers, and 15-year-olds are part of this group.
Some educational systems or cultures may define 'teenager' differently, such as starting at age 12 or ending at age 18.
The widely accepted international standard for 'teenager' is ages 13-19, as reflected in most educational and legal systems.
Not all children born in 2010 will turn 15 in 2025 due to variations in birth dates and time zones.
The vast majority of children born in 2010 will indeed turn 15 in 2025, making the claim statistically valid.

supporting.text: Legal definitions in many jurisdictions recognize individuals aged 13-19 as teenagers, and 15-year-olds qualify under this classification.

attacks.text: Legal definitions in many jurisdictions recognize individuals aged 13-19 as teenagers, and 15-year-olds qualify under this classification.
Some jurisdictions or cultural contexts may define 'teenager' differently, such as starting at age 12 or ending at age 18, which could exclude 19-year-olds.
The majority of legal and common usage globally aligns with the 13-19 definition, making exceptions statistically rare and context-specific.
The claim assumes all children born in 2010 will reach 2025, ignoring mortality or edge cases like leap years affecting birthdate calculations.
Mortality rates for this age group in most countries are negligible, and leap years do not affect year-based age calculations.

supporting.text: Cultural and social norms widely accept that individuals aged 15 are teenagers, as they are no longer children but not yet adults.

attacks.text: Cultural and social norms widely accept that individuals aged 15 are teenagers, as they are no longer children but not yet adults.
Some cultures define 'teenager' differently, with certain societies considering individuals as teenagers only after specific rites of passage, regardless of age.
Rites of passage are often symbolic and do not change the biological or chronological definition of a teenager, which is universally tied to ages 13-19.
Legal definitions in some countries may classify 15-year-olds as minors or juveniles rather than teenagers, depending on the context (e.g., criminal responsibility).
Legal classifications are context-specific and do not override the general linguistic and social understanding of 'teenager' as someone aged 13-19.
